comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
@adityapatwardhan all tests should begin at CI scope until found to be overly slow and low risk.

Especially considering we have 13 non CI test regressions already.

comments.author: Francisco-Gamino
comments.body: @adityapatwardhan --For the Windows scenario, we need to install the help files for Microsoft.PowerShell.Core. Should I added the files via nuget package (this is the Linux scenario because update-help does not work)? or should I call update-help -module microsoft.powershell.core?

comments.author: Francisco-Gamino
comments.body: @adityapatwardhan The main issue on Linux is that update-help does not work, so this is the reason why we created the nuget package with the help files. For windows on the other hand, I was thinking to download the help content for Microsoft.PowerShell.Core and check in with the tests. Then, when the tests are run, on Windows, we will call update-help -sourcepath <path to cab>. This way, we do not have to make a call outside. Thoughts?

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body: So how does .NET Core restore NuGet pkgs?  I know they don't use nuget.exe because I've seen issues on why that isn't cross-plat.  But somewhere, someone on .NET Core has implemented the ability to at least pull pkgs from NuGet.  Any chance the team could get their hands on that code?

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: @rkeithhill That's the funny thing, it does use NuGet! The command is `dotnet restore` but it actually invokes NuGet [underneath](https://github.com/dotnet/cli/blob/rel/1.0.0/src/dotnet/commands/dotnet-restore/NuGet3.cs), which is indeed [cross platform](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/tree/dev/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat).

comments.author: Francisco-Gamino
comments.body: @adityapatwardhan I've update the tests to install the help content using -sourcepath for CI, and update-help making a call to the download center for Feature tests.

comments.author: Francisco-Gamino
comments.body: @andschwa could you please integrate this PR when you have a moment? Thanks!

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: Checked with @Francisco-Gamino about the binary file. It's a quarter of a megabyte and unlikely to change frequently, so I'm okay committing it. It's a test asset that does not need to kept up-to-date and is simply to ensure CI can pass without fail (i.e. no transient networking problems).
